figure_1.title: Fig 1. Example happy and neutral face stimuli with opaque, clear, or no mask.
figure_1.caption: Face stimulus is modified and reprinted from the KDEF stimulus set (The Karolinska Directed Emotional Faces; [67]) under a CC BY license, with permission, original copyright [1998].

figure_2.title: Fig 2. Example trial depicting a happy emotional expression with a clear mask.
figure_2.caption: Face stimulus modified and reprinted from the KDEF stimulus set (The Karolinska Directed Emotional Faces; [69]) under a CC BY license, with permission, original copyright [1998].

figure_3.title: Fig 3. Mean empathy ratings as a function of emotion, mask, and mimicry.
figure_3.caption: Error bars depict standard error of the mean.

figure_4.title: Fig 4. Mean empathy ratings as a function of mask, emotion, and mimicry.
figure_4.caption: Error bars represent standard error of the mean.

claims.sentence: Fig 1 shows example stimuli.

At the start of each No Mimicry block conditions, participants were shown an image of a face holding a pen between their teeth and were instructed, “For the entire duration of this block, please position the object as shown below and hold it there while you complete the trials.” At the start of each Spontaneous Mimicry conditions, participants were shown an image of a face with a neutral expression and no pen, paired with the instruction, “For the entire duration of this block, please make sure the object is removed from your mouth and keep your face relaxed into its normal state.”
The same face identities were presented in both the No Mimicry and the Spontaneous Mimicry conditions.Procedure
Fig 2 illustrates an example trial sequence.
Fig 3 plots the mean empathy ratings as a function of Emotion, Mask, and Mimicry.
Fig 4 illustrates the mean Empathy ratings as a function of Emotion, Mask, and Mimicry.
Fig 1 shows example stimuli.
